thread.section_title: Car & Bike reviews, upcoming cars in India, news | MSN India
thread.title: Vespa RED launched at Rs 87,099
thread.title_full: Vespa RED launched at Rs 87,099

posts.author: Neil Nair
posts.title: Vespa RED launched at Rs 87,099
posts.text:
Vespa RED launched at Rs 87,099 Bikewale 03-10-2017 Neil Nair Piaggio has launched the Vespa RED scooter in India at Rs 87,009(ex-showroom, Mumbai). The scooter is based on the VXL 125 and features an all-red theme.
The Vespa RED is a collaboration between Piaggio and charitable organisation, RED. The scooter is built to contribute to a good cause as $50 from the sale of each unit of the Vespa RED will go to support the fight against AIDS.
Underneath the RED theme, the scooter is a VXL 125. It uses a 125cc air-cooled engine that produces 9.90bhp and 10.60Nm of torque.
© BikeWale Vespa RED launched at Rs 87,099 When the Vespa RED initiative was launched in 2016 in Rome, Piaggio used the 946. The 946 was recently discontinued in India as it did not do well due to its heavy price tag. This Vespa RED is made exclusively for India.
The scooter will not have any competition in the Indian market although it is priced close to the SXL 125 and VXL 150. Bookings for the scooter have already begun and deliveries will commence by next month.

thread.title: TVS Jupiter 125 spied testing in India, to be priced around Rs 58,000
thread.title_full: TVS Jupiter 125 spied testing in India, to be priced around Rs 58,000

posts.author: FE Online
posts.title: TVS Jupiter 125 spied testing in India, to be priced around Rs 58,000
posts.text:
TVS Jupiter 125 spied testing in India, to be priced around Rs 58,000 03-10-2017 FE Online © image If rumour-mill is to be believed, TVS is working on a new 125 cc Jupiter scooter in India and some spy shots of a completely camouflaged scooter have surfaced recently. It is expected that the upcoming scooter from TVS is likely to be the Jupiter 125 and might be powered by a new 125 cc single-cylinder fuel-injected engine. TVS, however, has not yet confirmed anything about the scooter. The new engine is expected to produce more power at around 8.5 hp than the current 110 cc unit's output of 8 hp. The automatic CVT transmission is expected to remain the same as in the present model.
Also read on MSN: Royal Enfield 750cc motorcycle may debut in November
Similar to the 110 cc version, the Jupiter 125 in its top-version could come with features such as alloy wheels and front disc brakes along with some other minor changes. The new TVS Jupiter 125 is also likely to get a telescopic suspension at the front and gas charged monoshock at the rear, similar to the ongoing model. However, the company might calibrate the suspension setup for better handling and performance.
Also read on MSN: Kawasaki India launches Z900 limited edition
The 110 cc TVS Jupiter is priced between Rs 50,051 and Rs 54,651, ex-showroom, Delhi and prices of the new Jupiter 125 are expected to start from Rs 58,000. When launched, it will compete with the likes of the Honda Activa 125, Suzuki Access 125, Mahindra Gusto 125 and other 125 cc scooters in the segment.
Recently, TVS also introduced a new Classic Edition of the Jupiter in the country that features retro styling. The scooter features a front windscreen, chrome finished round rear view mirrors, chrome finished pillion grab rail with backrest and dual tone seat with stitching details. It is powered by the same 110 cc engine as the standard model and the TVS Jupiter Classic Edition is priced at Rs 55,551, ex-showroom, Delhi.
Image Source: Team-BHP.com

thread.title: Tired of ghosting and other terrible dating trends? Try 'breezing' and make your love life easy
thread.title_full: Tired of ghosting and other terrible dating trends? Try 'breezing' and make your love life easy

posts.author: Dipannita Saha
posts.title: Tired of ghosting and other terrible dating trends? Try 'breezing' and make your love life easy
posts.text:
Tired of ghosting and other terrible dating trends? Try 'breezing' and make your love life easy India Today 3 days ago Dipannita Saha Truth be told, all these so-called dating trends had started making us lose faith in love and humanity altogether. Whether is stashing , breadcrumbing , or hyping --one dating trend is worse than the other. But, it's time to praise the dating Gods (if there are any), because there's a hot new dating trend on the block which is not at all negative! Behold 'breezing' that will make your love life as peaceful as a quaint breeze.
© India Today Group Praise the dating Gods people, there's a new dating trend 'breezing' on the block. Photo Courtesy: Youtube/TSeries What is this 'breezing' you ask? According to Esquire , it is a term used for when you say goodbye to the conventional "dating rules" and are straight-up honest, right from the beginning. Yes, that's right. You can come right out in the open about your expectations and feelings and say goodbye to mixed signals and mind games forever!
How did this term come in to be? Well, this method has been tried and tested by Jenna Dewan Tatum, and husband Channing Tatum says that Dewan admitting her feelings was, "the sexiest thing she'd ever done for me."
If you're still curious, here are four ways to ace the breezing game, and make your love life thandi hawa ka jhoka .
Stop Following Those Three-Day Stupid Texting Rules
You want to stop getting into complicated mathematical equations to find out if you should be messaging the guy? Then just message him. Enough of those three-day or four-day texting rules.
If You Were The Last One To Message, It Doesn't Matter
Imagine you were having a conversation with him last night and you ended up sending him the last message. Usually rules say that you let him initiate a conversation the next day. But, not anymore. So what you texted last? It's okay to be the one to initiate the conversation again, no second thoughts given.
If You Like Him, Just Tell Him
Leading someone on when you don't feel the same as they do is the worst thing you can do to someone. You like him? You tell him, girl. And if you don't, tell him that you are still figuring things out. Basically, breezing allows both of you the space to be honest, without hurting or leading the other on.
Figure Out If It's A Fling Or Something Serious
So you like him, but is it just a fling or something more than that? You see, it's very important to define a relationship. When you define something, you also clear out all the doubts that you may have in your mind regarding that person. Just figure out what it is--is it a fling? A relationship? Or just casual sex?
(Provided by Buzz60)

Marilyn Monroe was a true Hollywood icon, so it's only fitting that her final resting place be in LA.
The famous actress and model, who was born Norma Jeane Mortenson, was only 36 years old when she tragically died of barbiturate overdose on Aug. 5, 1962.
© Provided by Allure Media Pty Ltd Three days later, she was buried at the Westwood Village Memorial Park Cemetery, where her foster parents, Ana Lower and Grace McKee Goddard, were also buried, during a private ceremony with friends and family.
After actor Lee Strasberg performed a eulogy and Judy Garland's "Over the Rainbow" was played, Marilyn was placed at crypt No. 24 at the Corridor of Memories.
© Provided by Allure Media Pty Ltd While some of Hollywood's biggest stars are also buried in the cemetery, now including Playboy founder Hugh Hefner, who will be laid to rest next to Marilyn, it is the flower arrangement outside of her crypt that is the most fascinating aspect of her final resting place.

thread.title: 10 Signs You Are Settling For a Miserable Marriage
thread.title_full: 10 Signs You Are Settling For a Miserable Marriage

posts.author: Laura L Hernandez
posts.title: 10 Signs You Are Settling For a Miserable Marriage
posts.text:
10 Signs You Are Settling For a Miserable Marriage Popsugar 3 days ago Laura L Hernandez © StockSnap/ Elizabeth Tsung You don't go around announcing it, but people can tell your marriage . . . sucks. You alternate between hiding how bad it is by making everything look "Facebook perfect" and revealing to friends just how frustrated you are. Sometimes you think that maybe it's just how marriage is. Sometimes you wonder if maybe your expectations are too high. Either way, it's clear from the outside that you are settling for a miserable marriage, thanks to these 10 signs.
The two of you act differently around others.
© StockSnap/ William Stitt The two of you act differently around others. You cover up the unhappiness and try to make it look like "business as usual," but both of you are thinking that things are just not good at all!
Your partner is giving you crumbs of love . . . or vice versa. © StockSnap/ Evan McDougall Your partner is giving you crumbs of love . . . or vice versa. These crumbs of love aren't enough, and you or your partner constantly feels as if something is missing . . . as if either one of you has to beg for affection and love.
You are making up and breaking up like it's in the job description. © StockSnap/Christiana Rivers You are making up and breaking up like it's in the job description. The two of you threaten divorce and then make up more times than either of you can count. It's more dramatic than a soap opera!
Most of your time is spent wondering if all marriages are like this. © StockSnap/bardia hashemirad Most of your time is spent wondering if all marriages are like this. If you're really wondering if your marriage is normal . . . well, perhaps it's not! If you spend a lot of time comparing your marriage to others, not only is that a bad habit to get into and destructive, but it may also be because you're so unhappy and don't understand why.
You live parallel lives, frequently venturing off alone. © StockSnap/ Alexandr Baranets You live parallel lives, frequently venturing off alone. If the two of you aren't spending any time together and your existences run parallel, your marriage is most likely miserable.
One sign of a miserable marriage? Always waiting for your partner. © StockSnap/William Stitt One sign of a miserable marriage? Always waiting for your partner. Whether it's literally waiting for your spouse to show up or metaphorically waiting on your partner hand and foot, you're not in a happy marriage.
The bedroom is quiet. © StockSnap/ Tirachard Kumtanom The bedroom is quiet. You and your spouse rarely have sex. So rarely, in fact, that you are starting to feel very lonely. And unwanted.
You make so many wishes: wishing it were better . . . wishing he or she were different. © StockSnap/ Alexandr Baranets You make so many wishes: wishing it were better . . . wishing he or she were different. You have a million regrets about your marriage. Instead of thinking about real-life strategies to make it better at this point, you just wish it were different, but you know it's not. You know deep inside that you are unhappily married.
You're happier when he or she is not around. © StockSnap/Francesco Gallarotti You're happier when he or she is not around. You live for alone time. You envision the future without your spouse but never say this to him or her. You feel single, even though you certainly aren't.
Your daily mood? Sad. Depressed. Distracted. © StockSnap/ Aidan Meyer Your daily mood? Sad. Depressed. Distracted. Your friends and family hate seeing you this way. They notice how unhappy you are. People hate seeing you settle. Even you start to acknowledge your depressive state about your marriage, but you feel trapped and hopeless.
(Provided by Wochit)

thread.title: Why I ALWAYS Put My Husband Before My Child
thread.title_full: Why I ALWAYS Put My Husband Before My Child

posts.author: YourTango
posts.title: Why I ALWAYS Put My Husband Before My Child
posts.text:
Why I ALWAYS Put My Husband Before My Child YourTango 3 days ago YourTango © franckreporter/Vetta/Getty Images Couple hug Think I'm a selfish, terrible mother? Actually, the opposite is true.
"Are you and daddy getting divorced?"
I was four years old, sitting on the bathroom floor and chatting with my mom while she soaked in the tub, when I blurted out this question.
"No, of course not!" she immediately responded. "Why would you think that?" I don't remember what I said next, but somehow we moved on to a new topic.
Later, I heard her whispering on the phone about what I'd said. She must have been thinking, "How did my little girl, the one with the stay-at-home mom and Catholic upbringing, know about divorce?"
R ELATED GALLERY: The 12 Things You Should Tell Your Spouse Every Day for a Happier Marriage (Provided by Reader's Digest) The 12 Things You Should Tell Your Spouse Every Day for a Happier Marriage
It's not like my parents were screaming and slamming doors all the time. Their unhappiness wasn't supposed to be obvious, especially not to a little girl. But somehow, even at that young age, I could sense that my parents were deeply unhappy in their marriage.
Turns out they did get divorced — four years later, right around my eighth birthday. The quietly hostile relationship that my parents had when they were married bloomed into an outwardly hostile one during the split, and it stayed that way for years after the divorce papers were signed. By the time my sister and I were pre-teens, our dad had remarried and pretty much vanished from our lives.
The whole thing — the divorce, our father deciding to go his own separate way — was incredibly sad and unfortunate, but it taught me an important lesson: It's almost impossible to have a happy childhood if you have miserable parents.
At some point, I decided that if I were ever to get married and have kids, I would do everything I could to have a happy marriage that lasted for the long haul. And if that wasn't possible, then at least I would do my best to forge a positive relationship with my ex-husband for the sake of my kids.
Years later, I met an amazing man. I got married and we celebrated our tenth wedding anniversary this past June. We're very happy, and because I want to stay happily married and give our three-year-old son the kind of joyful home I didn't have while I was growing up, I put my marriage first.
That's right. My husband comes before anyone else in my life, including my beloved child. And I'll tell you why your husband is more important than your child.
Before anyone calls me a selfish, terrible mother, please let me explain what I mean by that; I think you'll see that it's not as harsh as it sounds. And, in fact, the priorities that we've set benefit everyone involved.
Putting my marriage first means I'm protecting the relationship that's central to Mason's happy childhood; I'm making sure that Chris and I coexist happily despite the changes that we experienced in our relationship after our baby was born, particularly in those first few months (from the way that we needed to divert our attention and, at times, affections to this new little person in our lives to the mind-boggling lack of sleep that lasted for months and made us argue about silly little things like who forgot to buy more coffee when the last bag ran out).
Putting my marriage first does not mean neglecting my son; Chris and I are extremely involved parents . We both say constantly that Mason is the love of our lives. He's the greatest thing we've ever done; we can't imagine our lives without him. We love him infinity plus.
So for Mason's sake (and for ours), here's how we make our marriage our top priority and why your husband is more important than your child, always.
1. We plan child-free couple vacations.
This isn't something my husband and I do every year; in fact, we've only done it once so far, but we plan on taking more trips alone in the future. Our first vacation a deux took place when Mason was six months old.
Too soon? No way. Chris and I needed to go somewhere and reconnect after my extremely difficult pregnancy (which included 30 weeks of morning sickness and extreme anxiety), so my mom graciously volunteered to come to New York to stay with him for five days. She insisted that we needed that time alone, even though I dreaded leaving the baby.
And you know what? She was right. Going on that trip was the best thing we could have done for our marriage . We had s**, we got some much-needed rest and we had wonderful dinners together. By the time we returned to New York, we were a stronger, happier couple — and ready to take on whatever Mason dished out. Bring on those sleepless nights, baby. We can handle it!
2. We present a united front.
This means we always have each other's back, no matter what. When Chris needed to take a job that would keep him in another city five days a week, I supported him. When I told Chris in September that I needed to leave my nightmare job and do something else, he supported me, no further explanation needed.
With Mason, it's all about being on the same page at all times; we never try to become the favorite parent by caving into what Mason wants versus what we believe is right. For example, I feel strongly that Mason needs to go to bed at 8 PM unless it's a special occasion. Chris, on the other hand, would be fine with letting him stay up later... but he knows this issue is important to me, so he respects my wishes.
We're being consistent with our messaging to Mason so that he doesn't get confused and so that he feels secure with a consistent routine. But more importantly, we're showing him that we're united in the decisions that we make, as well as demonstrating unequivocal support and respect for each other.
3. We keep the baby out of the bed.
Chris and I made a conscious decision from the very beginning not to co-sleep (although Mason's bassinet was in our bedroom for months) because we wanted a space where we could have s ** or cuddle without worrying about a baby sleeping between us. Now that Mason is a toddler, he will crawl into bed with us in the early morning hours, and we're not going to kick him out; we're more than happy (and grateful!) for that cuddle time.
But when it's time to go to sleep every night, it's just the two of us, no exceptions. And since that's always the way we've operated, we've never had an issue with Mason about it. He understands that this space is mommy's and daddy's special place, just like his room is his.
4. I respect my husband's needs (and he does the same).
Neither of us is a morning person , so we take turns getting up with Mason at the crack of dawn every day. Sometimes Mason insists that mommy (or daddy) needs to be up, too, and we're very clear that he gets the undivided attention of one parent every morning because mommy or daddy is tired and she/he needs some extra rest.
Or sometimes mommy needs to go to the gym alone, or daddy needs a night out with friends. We protect the other partner's needs out of love and respect. Those time-outs make us better parents — and better partners, too.
5. I recognize my husband's greatness (and he returns the favor ).
I am Chris' biggest fan (his publicist, even) and he's mine. We praise each other to other people, as well as to our son. Every morning when I come out into the living room, dressed for work, Chris points to me and says to Mason, "Isn't mommy beautiful?" When Chris cooks us one of his amazing dinners, I point to the food and say to Mason, "Isn't daddy the best cook?"
We compliment each other in front of Mason, both to build his respect and love for the other parent, as well as to show our love and appreciation for each other. It's our way of keeping the other partner from feeling unimportant, unnoticed, or on the back burner.
Heather Morgan Shott is a Midwesterner-turned-New Yorker. She's the founder of Founder of HighChairTimes and the EIC of Momtastic.

thread.title: Lava to launch six to seven new smartphone models priced under Rs 10,000
thread.title_full: Lava to launch six to seven new smartphone models priced under Rs 10,000

posts.author: Saaho: Another actress roped in for Prabhas's film
posts.title: Lava to launch six to seven new smartphone models priced under Rs 10,000
posts.text:
Lava to launch six to seven new smartphone models priced under Rs 10,000 India Today 19 hours ago © Provided by India Today Lava eyes bigger chunk of market with sub 10K mobile phones Homegrown handset maker Lava plans to focus on sub-Rs 10,000 mobile phones with 6-7 models in its portfolio to capture a bigger pie of the market in this price segment.
"We want to focus and dominate in the sub Rs 10,000 mobile phones segment with a portfolio of 6-7 models. Our strategy is to have limited number of products and drive volumes. With our R&D centre in Shenzhen in China, we are working hard to enhance customer experience," Lava International Head Smartphones Deepak Mahajan told PTI.
The company, which has presence in 11 countries, offers 8-9 feature phones and 6-7 smartphones. Lavas current market share, in the under Rs 10,000 price segment, is around 11 per cent.
Mahajan expects India to be become a hub for IT and handset makers and sees global brands emerging from the country. He also expects a big opportunity for his company.
He gave example of how giants such as Google and Facebook made it big from the US, Sony in Japan, Samsung, LG and South Korea and Huawei and Oppo in China. He expects similar opportunity to arise from India.
According to Counterpoint Research, under Rs 10,000 mobile phones contribute 59 per cent of the total smartphone sales in the country.
Lava has operations in 11 countries such as India, Thailand, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Nepal, the UAE, Indonesia, Mexico, Myanmar, Pakistan and Egypt.
The company reported a revenue of Rs 7,626 crore in the 2015-16 fiscal and 23 per cent growth as compared to the previous year.
When asked if the company is looking at foraying into new markets overseas this year, Lava International Senior VP Head of Product Gaurav Nigam said: "We will continue to grow and expand our business in new markets to make Lava products and services available to more customers."
Lava, which has a strength of 15,000 employees, plans to increase its head-count to close to 1 lakh in the next 8-10 years, Nigam said.
The company said that majority of the increased workforce will be in the manufacturing and field sales team.
On the China R&D centre, Nigam said: "With our established R&D centre based out of Shenzhen, Lava is in the process of spearheading the R&D road map among Indian manufacturers in the country...On an average, Lava develops about 8 smartphones and 3 feature phones per year at its China facility".

thread.section_title: MSN Money India | Latest Financial News, Market Updates and Guides
thread.title: These top Indian stocks seen extending rally after 400% surge this year
thread.title_full: These top Indian stocks seen extending rally after 400% surge this year

posts.author: Swansy Afonso
posts.title: These top Indian stocks seen extending rally after 400% surge this year
posts.text:
These top Indian stocks seen extending rally after 400% surge this year Livemint 6 days ago Swansy Afonso Mumbai: For these two Indian companies, the best may well be yet to come.
Graphite India Ltd and HEG Ltd are leading manufacturers of graphite electrodes, an essential component of electric arc furnaces that turn scrap into steel. They’re up more than 400% since the start of January, making them the best performers among global peers and Indian industrial companies.
© LiveMint HEG's shares have surged more than 500% in Mumbai this year, and those of Graphite India have rallied over 400%, the top gainers on the 225-member S&P BSE Industrials Index. The gauge is up 20%. Photo: Hemant Mishra/Mint The firms are riding a wave of demand as world steelmakers ramp up output in response to a slump in Chinese exports of the metal and the highest prices in more than four years. Meanwhile, cuts in electrode capacity have curbed supply, China’s clampdown on pollution has hurt production of electrodes and there’s a shortage of needle coke, the raw material used to make them.
Analysts expect the producers to rally further as earnings surge on increased sales and better prices. Brokerage Anand Rathi Financial Services Ltd raised its 12-month target for Graphite India last month to Rs524, 40% more than the closing price on Friday. Jefferies Group LLC sees HEG rising to Rs1,050 in 12 months from Rs933.20.
“There’s a global shortage of graphite electrodes,” Ravi Jhunjhunwala, HEG’s chairman, said in an interview. “The rest of the world is in better shape today because they are not seeing the dumping of steel from China, so the steel industry is picking up well in the last six months.” Spot electrode prices have risen 10-fold this year, according to research firm Kepler Cheuvreux.
The squeeze on supply has been worsened by cuts of about 20% in production capacity for graphite electrodes in the past four years because of an earlier drop in demand, Jefferies Group estimates. An environmental crackdown in China that is limiting capacity across heavy industries has also caused shortages of electrodes, according to Eurofer, the region’s steel lobby group, in a release last month.
Global peers of the Indian companies have posted healthy gains in 2017. Tokai Carbon Co. has jumped more than 170% in Japan, Showa Denko KK has more than doubled and Nippon Carbon Co. is up over 90%. SGL Carbon SE has climbed 70% in Germany.
Some manufacturers are consolidating. Showa Denko received US anti-trust approval last month to buy SGL Carbon’s global graphite electrode business in exchange for the sale of SGL’s US business to Tokai Carbon, almost a year after the company announced the deal.
Needle coke
European steelmakers say the shortage is threatening output as they’re dependent on imported graphite electrodes, with about 226,000 metric tonnes of them consumed each year in the European Union, according to Eurofer. “With Chinese supplies of needle coke and graphite out of the market, there’s a clear shortage of both materials,” it said. In Japan, Tokyo Steel Manufacturing Co. said higher costs are inevitable in the second half of the financial year.
Suppliers of needle coke, which represents as much as 60% of the cost of the electrodes, are trying to churn out more. C-Chem Co., a unit of Nippon Steel & Sumikin Chemical Co., is producing all it can from domestic coal tar, but is unable to meet demand, according to Hideo Ishii, a spokesman for the parent company. The global shortage has worsened after Hurricane Harvey hurt the operations of a key US supplier, said Jhunjhunwala.
HEG, which says it supplies mills such as ArcelorMittal, Posco and US Steel Corp., expects to operate at 85% capacity in the year through March, up from about 65% in the prior 12 months, said Jhunjhunwala. Any further increase in capacity use will be limited by the needle coke shortage, he said.
Rising prices put at risk annual purchasing contracts in the industry, Jhunjhunwala said. “I don’t think most of the electrode producers will be in a position at all to commit to 12-month contracts because of the needle coke shortages and the cost of raw material going up,” he said. They may move to a mix of spot, quarterly or half yearly deals, he said.
The company’s shares have surged more than 500% in Mumbai this year, and those of Graphite India have rallied over 400%, the top gainers on the 225-member S&P BSE Industrials Index. The gauge is up 20%. Bloomberg

thread.title: Samsung, IBM make beeline for IIT-D students; to offer Rs 20 lakh annual pay package
thread.title_full: Samsung, IBM make beeline for IIT-D students; to offer Rs 20 lakh annual pay package

posts.author: Vidya S
posts.title: Samsung, IBM make beeline for IIT-D students; to offer Rs 20 lakh annual pay package
posts.text:
Samsung, IBM make beeline for IIT-D students; to offer Rs 20 lakh annual pay package India Today 22 hours ago Vidya S Samsung, IBM, Oracle and Wipro are likely to hire Indian Institute of Technology-Delhi (IIT-D) students on the much sought-after Day 1 of campus placements, with annual pay packages of around Rs 20 lakh.
The firms are among the 40-odd that have registered for placement with the premier technological institute, where the pre-placement season has just begun.
Companies have given their pre-placement talks and five to six of them conducted tests to shortlist candidates, said final year students.
"Our CV verification process is going on," said a final-year mechanical engineering student who did not want to be named.
The first phase of placements will start around December 1. Hundreds of students, considered the brightest in the country, will vie for top jobs amidst the IT sector losing sheen over reported mass layoffs as skills turn obsolete due to automation and the Trump administration insisting on more employment for US nationals.
"Our placement officer did say there was a reduction in IT placements and an increase in manufacturing placements. They expect the trend to continue this year as well," said a final-year electrical engineering student.
The top-bracket salaries that these companies are offering indicate that they will hire on Day 1 , said two students appearing for placements. Usually, the biggest names in the field land on campuses early on in the season to lap up the creamiest of layers.
While they will hire software engineers, product developers and product engineers with coding knowledge, big management firms like AT Kearney, Bain & Company and Boston Consulting Group are expected to hire consultants and data scientists on Day 1. These roles are open to students of other branches of engineering as well. Private lenders Axis Bank and HSBC have also registered with IIT-D .
The placement process is set to gain momentum after October 22 when students return from the mid-term break. Software giants Microsoft and Google, and India's biggest e-commerce company Flipkart are also likely to join the list of recruiters by then, students said.
"I expect the number of recruiting companies to go up to 100-120 by October end," the mechanical engineering student said.
However, the electrical engineering student said the mood on the campus is a lot better than what it was last year. "Lots of firms are coming and tests are happening. It should be better than last year, when it was bad. We feel positive."
With reports saying many lost their jobs because of not upgrading their skills, students are rushing to learn some of these subjects, he said. "Machine learning is pretty hot right now. VLSI chip design is another area that students are keen on. Students also take up finance and marketing courses at the MBA department to prepare for consultancy jobs.'' IBM is hiring for a machine learning role, he added. Not many startups have registered so far, with California-based cloud services firm Rubrik being the only attractive one on the list, students said.
Many startups, including Zomato, Portea Medical and Hopscotch , were blacklisted from the institute's placements last year because they later withdrew the offers made to students. However, the ban has been lifted.
This year startups will reportedly be bunched together on one day called 'Startup Day', which will be slotted way below on the fourth or fifth day of placements. Students may also be told to conduct their own checks before accepting an offer from a startup.
The ban being revoked has not made a huge difference to students, according to a final-year textile engineering student.
"However, the good thing about startups is that many of them will consider even students from non-IT backgrounds if they know coding. That's not something a Microsoft or a Google would do. Sometimes, startups even hire for non-core positions like business development," he said.

thread.section_title: MSN Entertainment News
thread.title: Tom Petty's Daughter AnnaKim Violette Shares Musical Memories With Her ‘Angel’ Dad in Moving Instagram Posts
thread.title_full: Tom Petty's Daughter AnnaKim Violette Shares Musical Memories With Her ‘Angel’ Dad in Moving Instagram Posts

posts.author: Leena Tailor‍
posts.title: Tom Petty's Daughter AnnaKim Violette Shares Musical Memories With Her ‘Angel’ Dad in Moving Instagram Posts
posts.text:
Tom Petty's Daughter AnnaKim Violette Shares Musical Memories With Her ‘Angel’ Dad in Moving Instagram Posts ETOnline 14 hrs ago Leena Tailor‍ Tom Petty’s daughter, AnnaKim Violette, paid tribute to her dad with a string of social media posts on Monday.
Petty suffered cardiac arrest "and was taken to UCLA Medical center but could not be revived,” Tony Dimitriades, longtime manager of Tom Petty & The Heartbreakers, said in a statement on behalf of the musician’s family. "He died peacefully at 8:40pm PT surrounded by family, his bandmates and friends."
“I love you my angel 💜,” Violette captioned a throwback photo of her dad on Monday afternoon.
I love you my angel 💜
A post shared by Ilovemyfamily (@dadlivesmatteronelove) on Oct 2, 2017 at 2:58pm PDT
In her posts, Violette shared how, as soon as she received the call to go to the hospital, she grabbed a special memento that Petty had made for her when she was younger.
“My dad had matching stage clothes made for me as a kid,” she shared along with a photo of the black jacket. “This jacket still fits me made by glen Palmer from granny takes a trip when I got the call to come to the hospital I grabbed this jacket and I'm still wearing it.”
My dad had matching stage clothes made for me as a kid this jacket still fits me made by glen Palmer from granny takes a trip when I got the call to come to the hospital I grabbed this jacket and I'm still wearing it⚡️
A post shared by Ilovemyfamily (@dadlivesmatteronelove) on Oct 2, 2017 at 3:52pm PDT
She then reminisced about her musical memories with her dad.
“96 tears was the first song my dad taught me to play,” she captioned an emotional selfie. “Thank you for all the love this has been the longest day of my life💜.”
96 tears was the first song my dad taught me to play thank you for all the love this has been the longest day of my life💜
A post shared by Ilovemyfamily (@dadlivesmatteronelove) on Oct 2, 2017 at 3:56pm PDT
Petty’s bandmates were also by his side, according to another of Violette’s posts, which featured an old pic of Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers.
“Band is here with my dad sweetest coolest people 💜🇺🇸💜we are one,” she wrote.
Band is here with my dad sweetest coolest people 💜🇺🇸💜we are one
A post shared by Ilovemyfamily (@dadlivesmatteronelove) on Oct 2, 2017 at 5:16pm PDT
Her tributes also featured an appeal for privacy during what she described as a “beautiful and private time.”
“Send love I’m asking for privacy and respect from strangers during this time,” she wrote. “I love you and send love to you and your family this is a beautiful and private time I love u dad.”
Send love Im asking for privacy and respect from strangers during this time I love you and send love to you and your family this is a beautiful and private time I love u dad
A post shared by Ilovemyfamily (@dadlivesmatteronelove) on Oct 2, 2017 at 1:02pm PDT
We love u
A post shared by Ilovemyfamily (@dadlivesmatteronelove) on Oct 2, 2017 at 12:33pm PDT
We are all a mirror of divine love
A post shared by Ilovemyfamily (@dadlivesmatteronelove) on Oct 2, 2017 at 12:41pm PDT

thread.section_title: MSN Entertainment News
thread.title: DJ Khaled and Ed Sheeran Respond to Vegas Shooting at 'TRL' Premiere: 'We Have to Come Together' (Exclusive)
thread.title_full: DJ Khaled and Ed Sheeran Respond to Vegas Shooting at 'TRL' Premiere: 'We Have to Come Together' (Exclusive)

posts.author: Alex Ungerman‍
posts.title: DJ Khaled and Ed Sheeran Respond to Vegas Shooting at 'TRL' Premiere: 'We Have to Come Together' (Exclusive)
posts.text:
DJ Khaled and Ed Sheeran Respond to Vegas Shooting at 'TRL' Premiere: 'We Have to Come Together' (Exclusive) ETOnline 1 day ago Alex Ungerman‍ DJ Khaled is trying to respond to Sunday's horrific Las Vegas shooting with love and positivity.
The "I'm the One" artist and Ed Sheeran were the first guests at the newly relaunched TRL premiere on Monday, where they responded to the domestic terror attack at the Mandalay Bay Resort, where a gunman opened fire at a country music festival, killing at least 59 people and wounding over 500 more.
"My prayers go out to everybody in Vegas. The whole world, we gotta pray more. Love is the key, love is the answer, we have to come together and help each other more, this is tragic," Khaled implored. "When I woke up this morning, I was like, 'What is going on?'"
"I'm sending all my love to all the families out there," he added. "Hopefully they can rise up and overcome this."
"It's all about love and unity and there's not much else we can do, really," Sheeran chimed in, echoing Khaled's statement.
"I'm a father, so I'm praying," Khaled added, referencing his adorable 11-month-old son, Asahd, who joined him for the premiere.
But will Asahd be a TRL regular? "He got his nap times, so he's the boss, the king! A young mogul," the proud papa said. "When he's ready to go he's always invited. Everywhere I go, my son is with me. That's my life."
Meanwhile, ET also talked to TRL c o-host Tamara Dhia about how they planned to handle the horrific events.
" TRL is not just a place where we talk about music, but it's also a place where we talk about real-life events," Dhia explained to ET. "We're all affected by this tragedy, and we're hoping that we can maybe be a place of comfort for the children. From MTV and TRL , our prayers and our condolences to everyone in Las Vegas."
Watch the video below for more.

posts.author: Justin Kirkland
posts.title: 'DWTS' opens with moment of silence, no eliminations
posts.text:
'DWTS' opens with moment of silence, no eliminations USA TODAY 3 days ago Justin Kirkland Click to expand Replay Video UP NEXT Fans out in force for NYC Comic Con CBS2's Vanessa Murdock got up close with the costumed characters at New York Comic Con. CBS New York 'Stranger Things' have happened! Netflix to raise prices this month Expect to pay more to watch the second season of Stranger Things. Netflix is raising its prices. Nathan Rousseau Smith (@FantasticMrNate) has the story. Buzz60 Hugh Hefner biopic will star Jared Leto Jared Leto is set to play Hugh Hefner in a biopic, announced not even one week after the Playboy founder's death. zoomin.tv 1 Cancel SETTINGS OFF HD HQ SD LO 'DWTS': See which stars are dancing USA TODAY See more videos SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL What to watch next Fans out in force for NYC Comic Con CBS New York 2:16 'Stranger Things' have happened! Netflix to raise prices this month Buzz60 1:07 Hugh Hefner biopic will star Jared Leto zoomin.tv 0:50 Critically acclaimed Cartoon 'Bob's burger' making way to big screen Newsy 1:06 The Time Tom Petty Went to War Against His Record Label Over $1 Money 1:35 DC to build on success of "Wonder Woman" with Justice League movie Newsy 1:44 The show goes on for Celine Dion and other celebrities in Vegas Inside Edition 1:35 How a state is using Taylor Swift to crack down on distracted drivers Buzz60 1:04 Tom Petty Dead at 66 ETonline 1:24 Tom Petty's most memorable songs CNN 1:24 Tom Petty: Beautiful that songs touch people (2005) CNN 1:12 Ron Charles runs across Spain to crack Dan Brown's latest code The Washington Post 2:29 10 new shows you should be watching this fall USA TODAY 1:22 Toymaker's retro cars attract both adults and kids CBS News 5:35 EXCLUSIVE: Go Behind the Scenes of OneRepublic's 'Rich Love' Music Video ETonline 0:53 Colbert issues awkward picture challenge CNN 1:15 UP NEXT Tom Bergeron opened up the night with a moment of silence in honor of the victims of the shooting in Las Vegas Sunday night . And it was welcomed — a moment to breathe. A moment to appreciate life and enjoy a little TV. A moment to remember that we're fortunate to have such a luxury.
So, let’s take a couple hours and let go.
The world is, well, it’s dark, y’all. But in the name of Tom Bergeron — the show must go on. And it's "Guilty Pleasure Night." So let’s focus on being kind. Let’s focus on sparkles. Let’s focus on dancing in sequins. And you know? Let’s not worry about who’s going home either, because this week, it’s no one. And if you didn’t really soak up that kindness message, take a page from Tom, and let’s get to reviewing the night. © Lou Rocco, AP Season 25 of 'Dancing with the Stars' premieres Monday.
Best of the rest Lindsey Stirling and Mark Ballas: 27/30
Guilty pleasure: pajamas all day
CALL UPON THE NAME OF STACY KEIBLER IF YOU’RE NOT WORTHY! Lindsey and Mark are doing a jive to Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go ! Can you imagine? It’s an iconic routine from Keibler in Season 2, but even still, Lindsey and Mark did not do so bad. The judges call it iconic, and it was great, but let’s be honest — it’s no Stacy Keibler. It’s enough to solidify 9s across the board though.
Jordan Fisher and Lindsay Arnold: 25/30
Guilty pleasure: comic books
LOL, these guilty pleasures are incredible. But at the core of the absurdity is incredible arts lover and Charleston experts, Jordan Fisher and Lindsay Arnold who, dare I say, just did a routine that should be Dancing with the Stars CANON. It’s like, professional comic book art. The choreography, the music, and the set are all perfect (even if it didn’t meet Len’s standard of Charleston), and it’s more than deserving of the season’s first 10.
Vanessa Lachey and Alan Bernstein: 23/30
Guilty pleasure: girls night out
So, Vanessa is like a low key Chrissy Teigen, you know? But when she’s on the dance floor, she looks like a pro. She gets a couple dings for a wobble or two, but she still manages to shine with a 23, and that’s not bad, y’all. Vanessa Lachey is the kind of stuff final threes are made of.
Best of the rest Nikki Bella and Artem Chigvintsev: 21/30
Guilty Pleasure: 50 Shades of Grey
Okay, weird elevator dance sequence! I see you! Some stars just connect from night one, and Nikki did not do that for us. But, you know what? She’s making some serious ground up, and her Viennese Waltz to Love on the Brain is the kind of performance that could legitimately take her to the end.
Drew Scott and Emma Slater: 23/30
Victoria Arlen and Val Chmerkovskiy: 22/30
Frankie Muniz and Witney Carson: 21/30
Nick Lachey and Peta Murgatroyd: 21/30
Derek Fisher and Sharna Burgess: 21/30
Terrell Owens and Cheryl Burke: 21/30
Sasha Pieterse and Gleb Savchenko: 19/30
USA TODAY Sparkle Points Podium Sasha Pieterse: 5/5
Gimmicks. Are. Wonderful. So when Sasha and Gleb rolled up as full-bedazzled chefs, you can’t help but cheer. The jazz routine didn’t get five starts, but the gimmick was perfect.
Nick Lachey: 4.5/5
We see you, overwrought '80s rom com chic. A lot of pastels and rhinestones. A lot of workout gear. A call back to Love Actually . It’s all the stuff of wardrobe champions.
Jordan Fisher: 4/5
When you dye your hair to match your ensemble, there’s something to be said about that. And when that ensemble is like... a lycra-looking light blue jumpsuit.

thread.title: The Voice recap: 'The Blind Auditions, Part 3'
thread.title_full: The Voice recap: 'The Blind Auditions, Part 3'

posts.author: Amanda Bell
posts.title: The Voice recap: 'The Blind Auditions, Part 3'
posts.text:
The Voice recap: 'The Blind Auditions, Part 3' Entertainment Weekly 2 days ago Amanda Bell © Trae Patton/NBC Jennifer Hudson might be new to The Voice’ s stateside scene, but she’s already developing her own sort of feud here with a co-coach. Surprisingly enough, it’s Blake Shelton she seems to have to square off with the most because it turns out they have similar taste.
Meanwhile, Adam Levine and Miley Cyrus’ interests are also starting to run in a similar vein — she might be leaning heavy on the country crooner side of things lately, but she still has a deep interest in rock, too, so she’s able to scoop up talent from a multitude of genres, much to Adam’s chagrin.
Let’s take a look at who comes out for round three of The Voice ‘s blind auditions.
Adam Cunningham (38 – Nashville, Tennessee)
“Midnight Rider” by The Allman Brothers Band
Imagine you’re playing some kind of Sims game where you have to make the perfect contestant for Team Blake. That’s Adam Cunningham. From his familiar locale — the man actually records songwriter demos in Blake Shelton’s old studio — to the hip country clothes to his steely vocals (which have a strong Charlie Daniels persuasion), it’s a match made in Nashville.
Jennifer Hudson tries to throw her hat (but not shoe) into the ring on account of the soul she heard beneath the brass and Southern sass, but Blake’s got this one in the bag.
Team : Blake
Hannah Mrozak (18 – Richfield, Wisconsin)
“Starving” by Hailee Steinfeld
With a pop starlet and an R&B diva on the coaching panel, it might seem a little strange for a fledgling female artist of those genres to bypass both in favor of Team Adam, but this time, he puts the “Adam” in adamant.
Hannah is still pretty new to the singing world and was inspired to pursue this passion by her late brother, who insisted music was her true future. Despite a shaky start, she manages to escape her nerves and deliver a pretty fearless effort at this note-scattered number, which would be very difficult for a less competent crooner. There are still some kinks to be worked out — or, as Adam might call them, “pocket issues” — but her vocal fluidity is undeniable and has a place here in this competition.
Team : Adam
Shilo Gold (26 – Denver, Colorado)
“Stay With Me (Baby)” by Lorraine Ellison
Miley Cyrus seems to always get at least one sure fit for her team — the last season she coached, it was Darby Walker. This time, it looks like Shilo Gold will do the honors. Because while she’s hardly a perfect singer — the beginning notes drag too far to the floor of her range, her high notes are off pitch, and even her full voice is a little inconsistent — there’s a familiar rasp to her voice that Miley thinks she can work with.
Shilo came into the night thinking she’d opt for Team Jennifer if she had the chance because she respects J. Hud’s ability to capture a room before even opening her mouth, but Miley’s promise to help her choose the right songs for her unique vocals wins the day this time.
Team : Miley
Samantha Rios (16 – Arlington, Virginia)
“Something’s Gotta Hold on Me” by Etta James
This season isn’t shaping up to be the one for the younger talents, like last year was. Samantha Rios here has some gumption that can’t be taught, but unfortunately there’s just not enough technicality in her tones to earn a chair turn. As Jennifer Hudson points out, it could be that the song just requires some range outside of her skill set — particularly when it comes to the super low notes that made Etta James so untouchable — but she’s definitely got some skill and performance savvy that she can hone and then come back and try out again.
Hey, she was brave enough to sing for the president of the United States, so a repeat audition on The Voice should be a cakewalk for this young lady.
Team : N/A
Noah Mac (17 – Dublin, California)
“Way Down We Go” by Kaleo
Every now and again, a singer comes along whose dedication to the performance is louder than his actual voice, and that seems to be the case with Noah Mac, who started singing at 8 years old during the memorial service for his own sister.
Noah claims to be inspired by soul and gospel music, and it shows in his Hozier-esque vocals. What really impresses Blake, though, is how well Noah is able to lift out of those low, growly notes and into his head space while still maintaining the “roundness” of his sound. While Jennifer Hudson is very complimentary about the effusiveness of his delivery, Blake wins the day by pointing out that Noah is emotionally equipped for the pressures of this competition already and can go far with the right leadership.
Team : Blake
Davon Fleming (30 – Baltimore, Maryland)
“Me & Mrs. Jones” by Billy Paul
You know Jennifer Hudson is interested in a singer when she not only throws a shoe but proceeds to do a duet with him. In this case, it’s for Davon Fleming, who’s got Stevie Wonder-level range and spirit as he belts out this number in his own, happy-go-lucky way.
Davon is a worship leader who’s clearly infected by persistent positivity, and all four coaches can’t help but turn around for him, whether they’ve got a legitimate shot at winning him over or not. Blake’s “I’ve won five times” bit is a no-go, and Miley’s name-dropping of Dolly Parton backfires when Jennifer Hudson takes that note to share the stage with Davon and sing “I Will Always Love You,” at which point it’s obvious they’re a perfect match. They even dress alike.
Team : Jennifer
Kathrina Feigh (24 – Philippines)
“Big White Room” by Jessie J
Move over, musical theater. Kathrina here put all her eggs in the music-theater basket throughout her education, but she’s ready to step out into a solo spotlight. And The Voice might be a good place for her to do just that, because with the size of her voice and the range that comes naturally to her, the rest can definitely be coached.
Her delivery sounds a lot like Ingrid Michaelson, but she’s also got some ambitiousness that seems to stretch her beyond her comfort zone. With Jennifer “If you can think the note, you can sing it” Hudson herself as her coach, she’s in good hands.
Team : Jennifer
Addison Agen (16 – Fort Wayne, Indiana)
“Jolene” by Ray LaMontagne
Some people just breathe music, and that’s definitely the case for Addison Agen. She doesn’t have a lot of worldly experience just yet — auditioning for The Voice marked her first trip on an airplane, even — but her dad owns a record store and her mom is a music therapist for senior citizens, so that folk singer quality comes naturally to her.
On the other hand, when Addison does try to stretch her octave, it sounds a touch forced. It’s her default voice that really lands, and that’s probably what gets the attention of Adam and Miley. In the end, she and Miley have a little more in common, as both have experience being underestimated for their youth, so we’ll have to wait and see if Miley has what it takes to groom Addison for the next level.
Team : Miley
Adam Pearce (31- New Orleans, Louisiana)
“Hot Blooded” by Foreigner
It’s a good thing Adam Levine has a great memory because when Adam Pearce comes back after being denied a spot in season 12, he’s looking at his name twin for the fateful turn. And turn Adam does. Adam No. 2 was critiqued and sent away for being a little too chaotic and unwieldy with his rock enthusiasm the first time, so he’s since consulted some vocal coaches to get the 411 on how to contain his screams.
This time, though he’s still rocking out with tubular enthusiasm to a tune that’s squarely in his wheelhouse, Adam No. 2 doesn’t lose control of his pitch the way he did last time, and he earns Adam’s bid — and Miley’s — for that reason. Miley doesn’t even put up much of a fight to recruit him; the Adams are clearly meant for each other in more ways than just a shared moniker.
Team : Adam
Myles Frost (17 – Washington, D.C.)
“My Cherie Amour” by Stevie Wonder
As much as talent matters on this show, a lot also rides on a contestant’s ability to choke back their nerves and provide a convincing showcase for the coaches — after all, all the coaches get to go off of is what they hear, and there are no second chances. But something tells me that if the coaches had the opportunity to see how much this young man oozes artistry, playing a litany of instruments and dancing with abandon, they might’ve been convinced.
Alas, it’s his shaky rendition of an already exacting number that ultimately informs their decision to pass on Myles Frost, although the coaches do heavily encourage him to come back with a little more preparation and confidence.
Team : N/A
Moriah Farmica (16 – Albany, New York)
“Crazy on You” by Heart
Most teenagers who come on this show probably don’t have the credentials or cool factor of this girl. Moriah Formica has been singing on a pseudo-professional level for a while now, opening for and then collaborating with Michael Sweet before she was even old enough for junior prom. And what’s even more impressive is that she absolutely shreds this song.
She’s got a composure that’s both stoic and radical, and, more importantly, she doesn’t waver in strength during her spot-on rendition of this outright power ballad. As Adam puts it during his sincere plea for her to join his team, she could easily sub in for Ann Wilson if Ann ever needed a sick day — it’s that on point. Ultimately, though, Moriah is wooed to Team Miley by her promises of big-sisterly advice and picking songs that will, like this one, let her blare her voice like she wants to. And you know what? That might just work. If this performance is any indication, Moriah’s got it all already and just needs an adequate jam platform. As Jennifer Hudson phrases it, she has “own[ed] her moment” here tonight.
Team : Miley
The rest:
Team Jennifer also added Alexandra Joyce, who did a delicate but pretty (from the sounds of the montage sample, at least) rendition of Taylor Swift’s “Wildest Dreams.” She also snagged Eric Lyn by default, since she was the only one to turn for his take on “Ooh Child” by The Five Stairsteps, citing his attention to every note. Meanwhile, Anna Catherine DeHart found herself on Team Blake after delivering a “cutting” performance of Maren Morris’ “I Could Use a Love Song.”
TEAM STANDINGS :
Team Adam : Dave Crosby, Brandon Showell, Dylan Gerard, Hannah Mrozak, Adam Pearce Team Miley : Janice Freeman, Brooke Simpson, Ashland Craft, Shilo Gold, Addison Agen, Moriah Formica Team Jennifer : Chris Weaver, Shi-Ann Jones, Lucas Holliday, Maharasyi, Davon Fleming, Kathrina Feigh, Alexandra Joyce, Eric Lyn Team Blake : Mitchell Lee, Esera Tuaolo, Keisha Renee, Red Marlow, Adam Cunningham, Noah Mac, Anna Catherine DeHart

posts.author: Alexandra Gibbs
posts.title: Stock futures point to higher open on Wall Street, after Dow closes 152 points up on Monday
posts.text:
Stock futures point to higher open on Wall Street, after Dow closes 152 points up on Monday CNBC 1 hr ago Alexandra Gibbs © Provided by CNBC U.S. stock index futures pointed to a slightly higher open Tuesday, with the positive trading streak for the fourth quarter set to continue, after Wall Street finished on a strong note in the previous session.
On the first trading day of 2017's fourth quarter , U.S. equities finished Monday's session on a strong note, not only closing at record highs but with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 152.51 points by the close. While this positive trading sentiment is set to continue, domestic and political news, however, are set to keep investors on edge.
 One of the key stories set to dominate talk Tuesday is that of Sunday's deadly shooting in Las Vegas. At least 59 people were killed and more than 500 were injured after a gunman opened fire on thousands of concertgoers at a country music festival. The incident has been categorized as the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history.
Elsewhere, eyes will be on U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday as he is set to travel to Puerto Rico, in light of the recent havoc inflicted on the Caribbean island by Hurricane Maria.
The natural disaster wiped out the power grid, while 88 percent of the cellphone sites in Puerto Rico still have no service and less than half of the nation's residents have access to running water, according to Reuters.
In commodities , oil prices showed signs of being under pressure during early market trade, as global supply glut concerns continued to weigh on investor sentiment. At 5.55 a.m. ET, U.S. crude fell slightly, trading around $50.46 per barrel, while Brent hovered around $55.91.
In earnings, Lennar (LEN) , and Paychex (PAYX) are set to report their latest financial figures.
In stocks news, investors are to keep an eye on the latest moves in defense and gun company stocks, following the massacre in Las Vegas, and Procter& Gamble is set to hold a webcast to answer shareholder questions.
Overseas, European stocks were trading relatively flat in market trade, while markets in Asia closed on a mixed note after the Reserve Bank of Australia chose to keep its rates unchanged Tuesday.
Follow CNBC International on Twitter and Facebook .

thread.section_title: Sports News, Scores, Schedules, Standings, Stats, Photos, Videos - MSN Sports
thread.title: 5 takeaways from the Chiefs' Week 4 win over Redskins
thread.title_full: 5 takeaways from the Chiefs' Week 4 win over Redskins

posts.author: John Dillon
posts.title: 5 takeaways from the Chiefs' Week 4 win over Redskins
posts.text:
5 takeaways from the Chiefs' Week 4 win over Redskins Chiefs Wire 6 hrs ago John Dillon Click to expand Replay Video UP NEXT Highlights: Chiefs drop Redskins to remain unbeaten Check out game highlights from the Week 4 matchup between the Washington Redskins vs. the Kansas City Chiefs. NFL Colts' Andrew Luck to return to practice this week Luck has been absent since having surgery on his throwing shoulder during the offseason USA Today Sports Video 5 takeaways from the Chiefs 29-20 victory over the Redskins Here are 5 takeaways from the Chiefs 29-20 victory over the Redskins Obligatory Alex Smith appreciation Harrison Butker is nails Bob Sutton needs to figure out how to use Justin Houston Tyreek Hill is fading in Kansas City’s offense Outside linebacker is a position of dire need USA Today Sports Video 1 Cancel SETTINGS OFF HD HQ SD LO 4 takeaways from Redskins' loss to Chiefs USA Today Sports Video See more videos SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL What to watch next Highlights: Chiefs drop Redskins to remain unbeaten NFL 6:03 Colts' Andrew Luck to return to practice this week USA Today Sports Video 0:38 5 takeaways from the Chiefs 29-20 victory over the Redskins USA Today Sports Video 0:52 Can't-Miss Play: Houston puts exclamation point on Chiefs win NFL 0:48 Braves GM Coppolella resigns CBS Sports 0:33 What the Vikings do at RB after Dalvin Cook injury CBS Sports 0:41 NFL Monday QB: Biggest surprise of the season CBS Sports 1:14 Week 4 Surprises: QB Jameis Winston CBS Sports 0:34 Watch the NFL's top plays from Sunday NFL 6:05 Week 4 Disappointments: WR Antonio Brown CBS Sports 0:23 NBA says players must stand for anthem NowThis News 1:54 Trubisky to start for Bears vs. Vikings CBS Sports 1:31 Highlights: Texans' Watson accounts for 5 TDs NFL 3:09 Believe it or not: Cam Newton is BACK! CBS Sports 1:15 Gurley on pace for historic season USA Today Sports Video 0:43 Appeals Court Set to Hear Elliott's Case Sports Illustrated 0:38 UP NEXT Kansas City showed some grit in their win over Washington on Monday Night Football, winning a close game against a surprisingly worthy opponent.
From the opening kickoff the Redskins seemed to have a physical edge over the Chiefs, but huge performances from rookies Kareem Hunt and Harrison Butker put Kansas City over the edge.
Though they'll mark it as a win, the Chiefs have a ton of room for improvement after Washington played them so close. With as many injuries as Washington suffered throughout the night, it was surprising that the game didn't get out of hand late.
HIGHLIGHTS: Chiefs move to 4-0
Guys like linebacker Justin Houston and cornerback Marcus Peters seemed to miss a beat on the biggest stage in football. Without their contributions to counter Washington's potent passing game, quarterback Kirk Cousins was able to gash Bob Sutton's defense for 258 combined yards rushing and passing.
This was a special game on a day that we all needed a break from reality. For now Kansas City remains undefeated, alone atop the NFL as THE team to beat. Here's what I saw in the Chiefs' huge win:
Obligatory Alex Smith appreciation
This is the part of the article that we acknowledge Smith's greatness. On a team that drafted his replacement months ago, Smith has found a way to revitalize his game to the tune of 9.21 yards per completion, a 77 completion percentage, and eight touchdowns without an interception.
If he keeps playing at this level, Chiefs management will need to seriously consider retaining him for 2018. It's fun to be excited about Patrick Mahomes, but for now I'm excited about Smith coming into his own.
Harrison Butker is nails
As sad as it was to see Cairo Santos get waived this week, it was so sweet to see Harrison Butker nail a game winner on Monday night. This kid who had never kicked in a regular season NFL game, let alone a Monday night game, made a GAME WINNING field goal after getting iced. With a crosswind.
This guy could stick around in Kansas City if he keeps making clutch kicks like he did against Washington.
Bob Sutton needs to figure out how to use Justin Houston
I've become something of a Sutton stan over the past few years, but nothing makes me question him more than seeing Houston one-on-one in pass coverage. It's almost like seeing a car going in reverse on the highway… it's just out of place and wrong. Houston didn't get a record-breaking deal in 2015 to get toasted by Vernon Davis on a go route.
The lack of a pass rush was palpable against Washington. Kansas City can't generate turnovers if they can't keep the offense off balance. With a premier pass rusher like Dee Ford out for the night, there is absolutely no reason to rush Frank Zombo instead of Houston. Do better, Sutton.
Tyreek Hill is fading in Kansas City's offense
This headline is misleading, but Hill certainly isn't the volume target we thought he would be going into the season. It's not so much that Hill isn't a part of the offense, but rather is playing the receiver position differently than the league has seen it played.
His role as a decoy and rusher on jet sweeps shouldn't be understated, but Hill is objectively the most dangerous with the ball in his hands. Teams are wising up on how to stop Kansas City's offense. If they're going to have success moving forward, Hill will need to see more touches.
Outside linebacker is becoming a position of dire need
It's so frustrating when injuries ruin depth at key positions. In Kansas City it seems like the outside linebackers are consistently thinned out, whether by Justin Houston's nagging knees or Tamba Hali's aging body. Now that Ford is on the injury report, Kansas City is down to Zombo and Terrance Smith to man the edge opposite Houston.
Kansas City is infinitely easier to attack when the game plan can be "run away from Houston." One of these younger Chiefs linebackers will need to step up and find a role to keep Zombo, a constant liability, off the field.
Related Slideshow: Best of the 2017 NFL Season (provided by photo services)
2017-18 NFL season

thread.title: 'DWTS' opens with moment of silence, no eliminations
thread.title_full: 'DWTS' opens with moment of silence, no eliminations

posts.author: Justin Kirkland
posts.title: 'DWTS' opens with moment of silence, no eliminations
posts.text:
'DWTS' opens with moment of silence, no eliminations USA TODAY 3 days ago Justin Kirkland Click to expand Replay Video UP NEXT Fans out in force for NYC Comic Con CBS2's Vanessa Murdock got up close with the costumed characters at New York Comic Con. CBS New York 'Stranger Things' have happened! Netflix to raise prices this month Expect to pay more to watch the second season of Stranger Things. Netflix is raising its prices. Nathan Rousseau Smith (@FantasticMrNate) has the story. Buzz60 Hugh Hefner biopic will star Jared Leto Jared Leto is set to play Hugh Hefner in a biopic, announced not even one week after the Playboy founder's death. zoomin.tv 1 Cancel SETTINGS OFF HD HQ SD LO 'DWTS': See which stars are dancing USA TODAY See more videos SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL What to watch next Fans out in force for NYC Comic Con CBS New York 2:16 'Stranger Things' have happened! Netflix to raise prices this month Buzz60 1:07 Hugh Hefner biopic will star Jared Leto zoomin.tv 0:50 Critically acclaimed Cartoon 'Bob's burger' making way to big screen Newsy 1:06 The Time Tom Petty Went to War Against His Record Label Over $1 Money 1:35 DC to build on success of "Wonder Woman" with Justice League movie Newsy 1:44 The show goes on for Celine Dion and other celebrities in Vegas Inside Edition 1:35 How a state is using Taylor Swift to crack down on distracted drivers Buzz60 1:04 Tom Petty Dead at 66 ETonline 1:24 Tom Petty's most memorable songs CNN 1:24 Tom Petty: Beautiful that songs touch people (2005) CNN 1:12 Ron Charles runs across Spain to crack Dan Brown's latest code The Washington Post 2:29 10 new shows you should be watching this fall USA TODAY 1:22 Toymaker's retro cars attract both adults and kids CBS News 5:35 EXCLUSIVE: Go Behind the Scenes of OneRepublic's 'Rich Love' Music Video ETonline 0:53 Colbert issues awkward picture challenge CNN 1:15 UP NEXT Tom Bergeron opened up the night with a moment of silence in honor of the victims of the shooting in Las Vegas Sunday night . And it was welcomed — a moment to breathe. A moment to appreciate life and enjoy a little TV. A moment to remember that we're fortunate to have such a luxury.
So, let’s take a couple hours and let go.
The world is, well, it’s dark, y’all. But in the name of Tom Bergeron — the show must go on. And it's "Guilty Pleasure Night." So let’s focus on being kind. Let’s focus on sparkles. Let’s focus on dancing in sequins. And you know? Let’s not worry about who’s going home either, because this week, it’s no one. And if you didn’t really soak up that kindness message, take a page from Tom, and let’s get to reviewing the night. © Lou Rocco, AP Season 25 of 'Dancing with the Stars' premieres Monday.
Best of the rest Lindsey Stirling and Mark Ballas: 27/30
Guilty pleasure: pajamas all day
CALL UPON THE NAME OF STACY KEIBLER IF YOU’RE NOT WORTHY! Lindsey and Mark are doing a jive to Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go ! Can you imagine? It’s an iconic routine from Keibler in Season 2, but even still, Lindsey and Mark did not do so bad. The judges call it iconic, and it was great, but let’s be honest — it’s no Stacy Keibler. It’s enough to solidify 9s across the board though.
Jordan Fisher and Lindsay Arnold: 25/30
Guilty pleasure: comic books
LOL, these guilty pleasures are incredible. But at the core of the absurdity is incredible arts lover and Charleston experts, Jordan Fisher and Lindsay Arnold who, dare I say, just did a routine that should be Dancing with the Stars CANON. It’s like, professional comic book art. The choreography, the music, and the set are all perfect (even if it didn’t meet Len’s standard of Charleston), and it’s more than deserving of the season’s first 10.
Vanessa Lachey and Alan Bernstein: 23/30
Guilty pleasure: girls night out
So, Vanessa is like a low key Chrissy Teigen, you know? But when she’s on the dance floor, she looks like a pro. She gets a couple dings for a wobble or two, but she still manages to shine with a 23, and that’s not bad, y’all. Vanessa Lachey is the kind of stuff final threes are made of.
Best of the rest Nikki Bella and Artem Chigvintsev: 21/30
Guilty Pleasure: 50 Shades of Grey
Okay, weird elevator dance sequence! I see you! Some stars just connect from night one, and Nikki did not do that for us. But, you know what? She’s making some serious ground up, and her Viennese Waltz to Love on the Brain is the kind of performance that could legitimately take her to the end.
Drew Scott and Emma Slater: 23/30
Victoria Arlen and Val Chmerkovskiy: 22/30
Frankie Muniz and Witney Carson: 21/30
Nick Lachey and Peta Murgatroyd: 21/30
Derek Fisher and Sharna Burgess: 21/30
Terrell Owens and Cheryl Burke: 21/30
Sasha Pieterse and Gleb Savchenko: 19/30
USA TODAY Sparkle Points Podium Sasha Pieterse: 5/5
Gimmicks. Are. Wonderful. So when Sasha and Gleb rolled up as full-bedazzled chefs, you can’t help but cheer. The jazz routine didn’t get five starts, but the gimmick was perfect.
Nick Lachey: 4.5/5
We see you, overwrought '80s rom com chic. A lot of pastels and rhinestones. A lot of workout gear. A call back to Love Actually . It’s all the stuff of wardrobe champions.
Jordan Fisher: 4/5
When you dye your hair to match your ensemble, there’s something to be said about that. And when that ensemble is like... a lycra-looking light blue jumpsuit.

thread.title: The Voice recap: 'The Blind Auditions, Part 3'
thread.title_full: The Voice recap: 'The Blind Auditions, Part 3'

posts.author: Amanda Bell
posts.title: The Voice recap: 'The Blind Auditions, Part 3'
posts.text:
The Voice recap: 'The Blind Auditions, Part 3' Entertainment Weekly 1 day ago Amanda Bell © Trae Patton/NBC Jennifer Hudson might be new to The Voice’ s stateside scene, but she’s already developing her own sort of feud here with a co-coach. Surprisingly enough, it’s Blake Shelton she seems to have to square off with the most because it turns out they have similar taste.
Meanwhile, Adam Levine and Miley Cyrus’ interests are also starting to run in a similar vein — she might be leaning heavy on the country crooner side of things lately, but she still has a deep interest in rock, too, so she’s able to scoop up talent from a multitude of genres, much to Adam’s chagrin.
Let’s take a look at who comes out for round three of The Voice ‘s blind auditions.
Adam Cunningham (38 – Nashville, Tennessee)
“Midnight Rider” by The Allman Brothers Band
Imagine you’re playing some kind of Sims game where you have to make the perfect contestant for Team Blake. That’s Adam Cunningham. From his familiar locale — the man actually records songwriter demos in Blake Shelton’s old studio — to the hip country clothes to his steely vocals (which have a strong Charlie Daniels persuasion), it’s a match made in Nashville.
Jennifer Hudson tries to throw her hat (but not shoe) into the ring on account of the soul she heard beneath the brass and Southern sass, but Blake’s got this one in the bag.
Team : Blake
Hannah Mrozak (18 – Richfield, Wisconsin)
“Starving” by Hailee Steinfeld
With a pop starlet and an R&B diva on the coaching panel, it might seem a little strange for a fledgling female artist of those genres to bypass both in favor of Team Adam, but this time, he puts the “Adam” in adamant.
Hannah is still pretty new to the singing world and was inspired to pursue this passion by her late brother, who insisted music was her true future. Despite a shaky start, she manages to escape her nerves and deliver a pretty fearless effort at this note-scattered number, which would be very difficult for a less competent crooner. There are still some kinks to be worked out — or, as Adam might call them, “pocket issues” — but her vocal fluidity is undeniable and has a place here in this competition.
Team : Adam
Shilo Gold (26 – Denver, Colorado)
“Stay With Me (Baby)” by Lorraine Ellison
Miley Cyrus seems to always get at least one sure fit for her team — the last season she coached, it was Darby Walker. This time, it looks like Shilo Gold will do the honors. Because while she’s hardly a perfect singer — the beginning notes drag too far to the floor of her range, her high notes are off pitch, and even her full voice is a little inconsistent — there’s a familiar rasp to her voice that Miley thinks she can work with.
Shilo came into the night thinking she’d opt for Team Jennifer if she had the chance because she respects J. Hud’s ability to capture a room before even opening her mouth, but Miley’s promise to help her choose the right songs for her unique vocals wins the day this time.
Team : Miley
Samantha Rios (16 – Arlington, Virginia)
“Something’s Gotta Hold on Me” by Etta James
This season isn’t shaping up to be the one for the younger talents, like last year was. Samantha Rios here has some gumption that can’t be taught, but unfortunately there’s just not enough technicality in her tones to earn a chair turn. As Jennifer Hudson points out, it could be that the song just requires some range outside of her skill set — particularly when it comes to the super low notes that made Etta James so untouchable — but she’s definitely got some skill and performance savvy that she can hone and then come back and try out again.
Hey, she was brave enough to sing for the president of the United States, so a repeat audition on The Voice should be a cakewalk for this young lady.
Team : N/A
Noah Mac (17 – Dublin, California)
“Way Down We Go” by Kaleo
Every now and again, a singer comes along whose dedication to the performance is louder than his actual voice, and that seems to be the case with Noah Mac, who started singing at 8 years old during the memorial service for his own sister.
Noah claims to be inspired by soul and gospel music, and it shows in his Hozier-esque vocals. What really impresses Blake, though, is how well Noah is able to lift out of those low, growly notes and into his head space while still maintaining the “roundness” of his sound. While Jennifer Hudson is very complimentary about the effusiveness of his delivery, Blake wins the day by pointing out that Noah is emotionally equipped for the pressures of this competition already and can go far with the right leadership.
Team : Blake
Davon Fleming (30 – Baltimore, Maryland)
“Me & Mrs. Jones” by Billy Paul
You know Jennifer Hudson is interested in a singer when she not only throws a shoe but proceeds to do a duet with him. In this case, it’s for Davon Fleming, who’s got Stevie Wonder-level range and spirit as he belts out this number in his own, happy-go-lucky way.
Davon is a worship leader who’s clearly infected by persistent positivity, and all four coaches can’t help but turn around for him, whether they’ve got a legitimate shot at winning him over or not. Blake’s “I’ve won five times” bit is a no-go, and Miley’s name-dropping of Dolly Parton backfires when Jennifer Hudson takes that note to share the stage with Davon and sing “I Will Always Love You,” at which point it’s obvious they’re a perfect match. They even dress alike.
Team : Jennifer
Kathrina Feigh (24 – Philippines)
“Big White Room” by Jessie J
Move over, musical theater. Kathrina here put all her eggs in the music-theater basket throughout her education, but she’s ready to step out into a solo spotlight. And The Voice might be a good place for her to do just that, because with the size of her voice and the range that comes naturally to her, the rest can definitely be coached.
Her delivery sounds a lot like Ingrid Michaelson, but she’s also got some ambitiousness that seems to stretch her beyond her comfort zone. With Jennifer “If you can think the note, you can sing it” Hudson herself as her coach, she’s in good hands.
Team : Jennifer
Addison Agen (16 – Fort Wayne, Indiana)
“Jolene” by Ray LaMontagne
Some people just breathe music, and that’s definitely the case for Addison Agen. She doesn’t have a lot of worldly experience just yet — auditioning for The Voice marked her first trip on an airplane, even — but her dad owns a record store and her mom is a music therapist for senior citizens, so that folk singer quality comes naturally to her.
On the other hand, when Addison does try to stretch her octave, it sounds a touch forced. It’s her default voice that really lands, and that’s probably what gets the attention of Adam and Miley. In the end, she and Miley have a little more in common, as both have experience being underestimated for their youth, so we’ll have to wait and see if Miley has what it takes to groom Addison for the next level.
Team : Miley
Adam Pearce (31- New Orleans, Louisiana)
“Hot Blooded” by Foreigner
It’s a good thing Adam Levine has a great memory because when Adam Pearce comes back after being denied a spot in season 12, he’s looking at his name twin for the fateful turn. And turn Adam does. Adam No. 2 was critiqued and sent away for being a little too chaotic and unwieldy with his rock enthusiasm the first time, so he’s since consulted some vocal coaches to get the 411 on how to contain his screams.
This time, though he’s still rocking out with tubular enthusiasm to a tune that’s squarely in his wheelhouse, Adam No. 2 doesn’t lose control of his pitch the way he did last time, and he earns Adam’s bid — and Miley’s — for that reason. Miley doesn’t even put up much of a fight to recruit him; the Adams are clearly meant for each other in more ways than just a shared moniker.
Team : Adam
Myles Frost (17 – Washington, D.C.)
“My Cherie Amour” by Stevie Wonder
As much as talent matters on this show, a lot also rides on a contestant’s ability to choke back their nerves and provide a convincing showcase for the coaches — after all, all the coaches get to go off of is what they hear, and there are no second chances. But something tells me that if the coaches had the opportunity to see how much this young man oozes artistry, playing a litany of instruments and dancing with abandon, they might’ve been convinced.
Alas, it’s his shaky rendition of an already exacting number that ultimately informs their decision to pass on Myles Frost, although the coaches do heavily encourage him to come back with a little more preparation and confidence.
Team : N/A
Moriah Farmica (16 – Albany, New York)
“Crazy on You” by Heart
Most teenagers who come on this show probably don’t have the credentials or cool factor of this girl. Moriah Formica has been singing on a pseudo-professional level for a while now, opening for and then collaborating with Michael Sweet before she was even old enough for junior prom. And what’s even more impressive is that she absolutely shreds this song.
She’s got a composure that’s both stoic and radical, and, more importantly, she doesn’t waver in strength during her spot-on rendition of this outright power ballad. As Adam puts it during his sincere plea for her to join his team, she could easily sub in for Ann Wilson if Ann ever needed a sick day — it’s that on point. Ultimately, though, Moriah is wooed to Team Miley by her promises of big-sisterly advice and picking songs that will, like this one, let her blare her voice like she wants to. And you know what? That might just work. If this performance is any indication, Moriah’s got it all already and just needs an adequate jam platform. As Jennifer Hudson phrases it, she has “own[ed] her moment” here tonight.
Team : Miley
The rest:
Team Jennifer also added Alexandra Joyce, who did a delicate but pretty (from the sounds of the montage sample, at least) rendition of Taylor Swift’s “Wildest Dreams.” She also snagged Eric Lyn by default, since she was the only one to turn for his take on “Ooh Child” by The Five Stairsteps, citing his attention to every note. Meanwhile, Anna Catherine DeHart found herself on Team Blake after delivering a “cutting” performance of Maren Morris’ “I Could Use a Love Song.”
TEAM STANDINGS :
Team Adam : Dave Crosby, Brandon Showell, Dylan Gerard, Hannah Mrozak, Adam Pearce Team Miley : Janice Freeman, Brooke Simpson, Ashland Craft, Shilo Gold, Addison Agen, Moriah Formica Team Jennifer : Chris Weaver, Shi-Ann Jones, Lucas Holliday, Maharasyi, Davon Fleming, Kathrina Feigh, Alexandra Joyce, Eric Lyn Team Blake : Mitchell Lee, Esera Tuaolo, Keisha Renee, Red Marlow, Adam Cunningham, Noah Mac, Anna Catherine DeHart
